Hi Ken,

The testing data is related to the same graph. I believe that ther=
e is some 
underlying geometry between the nodes in the graph, and there sh=
ould be some 
regularities in the connectivity. Other researchers have appl=
ied HMMs, Naive 
Bayes classifiers etc to solve this problem with limited r=
esults.

Thanks for the heads up.

Regards,
Mridul.







________________=
________________
From: Ken <kstanley@...>
To: neat@...=
m
Sent: Wed, November 3, 2010 9:57:13 PM
Subject: [neat] Re: Input encoding=
 with HyperNEAT

  


Mridul, where does the testing data (i.e. what you wi=
ll test it on after 
training is over) come from?  Is it from a different g=
raph or the same graph?  
The reason I ask is that it probably matters whet=
her the nodes will be the same 
nodes (i.e. because they are from the same =
graph) or nodes from an entirely 
different graph.

In general, it does sou=
nd like you could create an array of 9000 inputs and 
highlight the ones th=
at you are asking about.  The main question for HyperNEAT 
is whether those=
 9000 inputs can be situated in a meaningful geometry?  For 
example, is it=
 naturally 300x300?  Or maybe something else?  If there is a 
geometry to t=
hem, and if there are regularities in their connectivity, then in 
principl=
e HyperNEAT might be a good choice for learning that pattern.

Also, note t=
hat with 9000 inputs, there will generally be a computational cost 
to acti=
vating the network.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "p_mridul" <p_mridul=
@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> I am working on a bioinformatics problem, but it'=
s easier to talk about it in 
>graph theory terms....
> 
> I have a graph w=
ith a large number of nodes (~9000), and about 3000 edges 
>between the nod=
es... I am planning to feed this as training data, and then see 
>if the re=
sulting NN will predict the probability of an edge given any 2 nodes.
> 
> =
I have questions of how to encode the inputs... do I create an input array =
of 
>9000 inputs and pass in the couple of 1's corresponding to the nodes, =
or do I 
>choose 2 inputs & pass in the node numbers?
> 
> Thanks,
> Mridul=
.
>

      <p><br>
<br>
Mridul, where does the tes=
ting data (i.e. what you will test it on after training is over) come from?=
  Is it from a different graph or the same graph?  The reason I ask is that=
 it probably matters whether the nodes will be the same nodes (i.e. because=
 they are from the same graph) or nodes from an entirely different graph.<b=
r>
<br>
In general, it does sound like you could create an array of 9000 in=
puts and highlight the ones that you are asking about.  The main question f=
or HyperNEAT is whether those 9000 inputs can be situated in a meaningful g=
eometry?  For example, is it naturally 300x300?  Or maybe something else?  =
If there is a geometry to them, and if there are regularities in their conn=
ectivity, then in principle HyperNEAT might be a good choice for learning t=
hat pattern.<br>
<br>
Also, note that with 9000 inputs, there will generall=
y be a computational cost to activating the network.<br>
<br>
ken<br>
<br>
